Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Molecular Level Characterization of Amino Acids in Atmospheric Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship is focused on the investigation of amino acids in the atmosphere and their contribution to the nitrogen content of atmospheric particles. It will establish an instrumental method for characterizing amino acids in gas and particle phases. Samples from several recent field campaigns will be analyzed for amino acid content. This project will improve the understanding of how biological activities, both natural and anthropogenic, that lead to the emission of amino acids influence Earth's nitrogen cycle.

The specific objectives of the proposed project are to: (1) Calibrate the Semi-Volatile Thermal desorption Aerosol Gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer (SV-TAG) for targeted amino acids by using chemical standards, and compare it to a gas phase instrument, Cluster Chemical Ionization Mass Spectrometer (Cluster CIMS), and a particle phase instrument, two-dimensional GC with electron impact or vacuum UV ionization coupled to a high resolution time-of-flight MS (GCxGC-EI/VUV-HR-TOFMS); (2) Identify and quantify amino acids from SV-TAG data and filter samples collected during previous field campaigns in the Amazon Rainforest, Southeastern United States, and an indoor classroom; and (3) Determine the partitioning coefficients of targeted free amino acids in atmospheric aerosols from various environments. Large discrepancies between predicted and measured partitioning coefficients indicate that free amino acids are condensing and reacting in the particles. This supports the hypothesis that amino acids react in the particle phase to form stable, low volatility compounds that contribute to the observed excess nitrogen (i.e., difference between total nitrogen and inorganic nitrogen amounts) in atmospheric particles and fog/cloud droplets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric aerosol particles contain tens of thousands of compounds that originate from numerous sources and chemical reactions. Biological activities such as the decomposition of proteins produce reactive organic nitrogen compounds, such as amino acids and peptide fragments, that can enter the particle phase. These compounds and their impact on the physiochemical properties of atmospheric particles remains unknown primarily due to a lack of speciation of amino acids and peptides in atmospheric particles. This study aims to understand how current instrumentation measures amino acids and peptides in aerosol particles and then to identify and quantify their contributions in particles found in various locations around the world.

            Two instruments were used to study amino acids: semi-volatile thermal desorption aerosol gas chromatograph (SV-TAG) and a two-dimensional gas chromatography coupled to an electron impact high resolution time of flight mass spectrometer (GCxGC EI-HRToFMS). Both instruments thermally desorb samples at 320?C in the presence of helium flow. The desorbed compounds are then mixed with a derivatization agent to convert the polar functional groups into less polar groups that are GC amenable. Eight amino acids and a peptide standard mix were all desorbed and measured by these two instruments. The chosen amino acids spanned a wide range of functional groups: 1-2 amine groups, an aromatic ring, a carboxyamide group, 1-2 alcohol groups, and a di-sulfide bond.

            Results from measuring amino acid standards on the SV-TAG showed significant thermal decomposition. For example, glutamic acid, glutathione, glutamine, and glucosamine thermally decomposed into 2-pyrrolidone-5-carboxylic acid (also known as pyroglutamic acid). Furthermore, the SV-TAG is not sensitive to load mass loadings of amino acids. Therefore, samples need relatively high mass loadings (>5 ng per sample) for the thermal decomposition products to appear in the chromatograms. The GCxGC EI-HRToFMS exhibited better mass loading sensitivities but the same thermal decomposition challenges as the SV-TAG.

            Filters collected from the Amazon Rainforest, southeastern U.S., Beijing, and the Fire Lab (Montana) were analyzed on the GCxGC EI-HRTofMS for the identified thermal decomposition products of amino acids. Pyroglutamic acid was found from all collection locations and appears to occur more often in samples that were impacted by biomass burning plumes. The highest concentration occurred in an Engel Spruce burn at the Fire Lab where 0.2 g of pyroglutamic acid was produced per 1 kg of dry fuel burned. It is likely that pyroglutamic acid was produced during pyrolysis of the fuel instead of thermal decomposition of an amino acid in the instrument; however, these results cannot definitively conclude this point.

            Other amino acids may exist in atmospheric aerosol particles that were not studied here. As such, the mass spectral database was compiled on all the thermal decomposition products that form from the measurement of the eight amino acids and the peptide standard. More than 30 mass spectra, their corresponding retention indexes, and original amino acid/peptide were compiled into the library. This library is NIST compatible, making it easy to quickly classify unknown compounds in atmospheric samples based upon information on when/where that compound has previously been found. Furthermore, the library can be easily shared with collaborators and other members of the public. Once the library is expanded to include unknown compounds found from other samples, e.g. biomass burns, Amazon Rainforest, etc., it will be released for free access to the public. Ultimately, this mass spectral library will be useful for researchers to quickly share their knowledge on the thousands upon thousands of unknown compounds found in the atmosphere.

            In addition to studying the complexities of atmospheric aerosol particles, this project aimed to develop a cloud formation and climate dynamics workshop for high school students in conjunction with a high school chemistry teacher. A hands-on demonstration was created to illustrate the difference between chemical reactions to create particles and condensation to form cloud droplets. The phenomena connect to fundamental chemistry concepts of vapor pressure and acid-base reactions (such as those with amino acids) taught in honors and AP chemistry curricula.

            This two-year project discovered the significance of thermal decomposition of amino acids during thermal desorption of aerosol particle samples. Results strongly indicate that traditional methods of extracting collected particles via thermal means will obscure the amino acid content in atmospheric particles. Likely no current instrument is capable of speciating amino acids in aerosol particles, and future work requires developing an instrument that avoids thermal desorption. In the meantime, mass spectral library of the amino acid thermal decomposition products was developed to better identify potential sources of amino acids in particles. For example, pyroglutamic acid, a thermal decomposition product of several amino acids, was found in significant concentrations in biomass burning samples. Future work will continue to expand the mass spectral library to include more amino acids products and will be shared with public so more sources can be identified.
